columns.text: In this problem, we need to calculate the NPV of the decision to switch.

To decide if we will change the policy, we need to calculate the present value of the cash flow with new policy and the cost of switching. The switch should be made if the sum of PV of cash flow with new policy and the cost of switching is greater than zero. So, we need to calculate the NPV of switching, and if it is greater than zero, then the switch will be profitable.

Let's first identify the given data in a problem:

| Data        |Designation       | Amount |
| ------------- |:-------------:| -----:|
| Current price per unit     | P| \$81|
| Price per unit under new policy     | P$^{\prime}$     |\$84|
| Cost per unit | $v$     |    \$47 |
|Current quantity sold per month|Q|3,280|
|Quantity sold under new policy|Q$^{\prime}$|3,390|
|Monthly required return|R|0.023|

To calculate the NPV of switching, first, we will find the Incremental cash flow, and cost of new policy. 

Currently, company sales $P\cdot Q=\$81\cdot 3,280=\$265,680$. Variable costs over one period are $v\cdot Q=\$47\cdot 3,280=\$154,160$. So, the cash flow from old policy is 
$$\begin{align*}
\text{Cash flow from old policy}&=(P-v)\cdot Q\\
&=(\$81-\$47)\cdot 3,280\\
&=\$34\cdot 3,280\\
&=111,520\\
\end{align*}$$

If the company switches to a new policy, it will sell $Q^{\prime}=3,390$ units, and monthly revenues will increase to $P^{\prime}\cdot Q^{\prime}$, and cost will be $v\cdot Q^{\prime}$. It follows that 
$$\begin{align*}
\text{Cash flow from new policy}&=(P^{\prime}-v)\cdot Q^{\prime}\\
&=(\$84-\$47)\cdot 3,390\\
&=\$37\cdot 3,390\\
&=\$125,430\\
\end{align*}$$

Using that  the relevant incremental cash flow is the difference between the new cash flow and old cash flow, we get 
$$\begin{align*}
\text{Incremental cash inflow}&=\$125,430-\$111,520\\
&=\$13,910
\end{align*}$$

According to the new policy, the costs are also changing. A company will have to produce $3,390-3,280=110$ more units at a cost of $\$47\cdot 110=\$5170$. Also, sales are changing, so the sales that would have been collected this month under the current policy $\$81\cdot 3,280= 265,680$ will not be collected. The sum od these two components is the cost of the switch. Thus,
$$\begin{align*}
\text{Cost of switching}&=PQ+v(Q^{\prime}-Q)\\
&=\$81\cdot3,280+\$47\cdot (3,390-3,280)\\
&=\$265,680+\$5,170\\
&=\$270,850\\
\end{align*}$$

Now, we can calculate the NPV of  the switch as follows
$$\begin{align*}
\text{NPV of switching}&=-\text{Cost of switching }+\frac{\text{Incremental cash inflow}}{\text{Requited rate of return}}\\[15pt]
&=-\$270,850+\frac{\$13,910}{0.023}\\[15pt]
&=-\$270,850+\$604,782.61\\[15pt]
&=\$333,932.61
\end{align*}$$

Since NPV is greater than zero, the switch is profitable.
